prompt:
Given the following classification examples, annotate the unlabeled example with a prediction that must correspond to exactly one of the following labels: neg, pos. Each label is described as follows: negative: A negative movie review. positive: A positive movie review. Text: The concept of having Laurel & Hardy this time in the role of chimney sweepers works out surprisingly hilarious. It guarantees some funny situations and silly antics, from especially Stan Laurel of course as usual.

The movie also has a subplot with a nutty professor who is working on a rejuvenation formula. It doesn't really sound like a logical mix of story lines and incoherent but both plot lines blend in perfectly toward the memorable ending. It's still a bit weird but its funny nevertheless, so it works for the movie.

The supporting cast of the movie is surprising good. Sam Adams is great as the stereotypical butler and Lucien Littlefield goes deliciously over-the-top as the nutty professor.

The movie is filled with some excellent timed and hilarious constructed sequences, which are all quite predictable but become hilarious to watch nevertheless thanks to the way they are all executed. It all helps to make "Dirty Work" to be one of the better Laurel & Hardy shorts.

8/10 Label: pos Text: {text} Label:

invocation_context.text:
The idea of having Laurel & Hardy as chimney sweepers in this film is surprisingly hilarious. It provides plenty of funny situations and silly antics, particularly from Stan Laurel as usual.

There is also a subplot involving a nutty professor who is working on a rejuvenation formula. It may not sound like a coherent mix of storylines, but both plots blend together perfectly towards the memorable ending. It may be a bit strange, but it's still funny and it works for the movie.

The supporting cast in the film is surprisingly good. Sam Adams is excellent as the stereotypical butler, and Lucien Littlefield delivers a delightfully over-the-top performance as the nutty professor.

The film is filled with excellently timed and hilariously constructed sequences. They may be predictable, but the execution is what makes them so funny to watch. All of these elements come together to make "Dirty Work" one of the best Laurel & Hardy shorts.

Rating: 8/10

prompt:
Given the following classification examples, annotate the unlabeled example with a prediction that must correspond to exactly one of the following labels: neg, pos.

Each label is described as follows:
negative: A negative movie review.
positive: A positive movie review.

Text: Ok, at the beginning it looked like "Shrek" - the loner that is persistently followed by the comic relief. Then it evolves into something really compelling, as the gauntlet is set. And the result is an enjoyable movie, which has moments that I agree that are a little too dramatic for kids to watch (Manny's past, for example). The premise has been obviously worked for a long time, so that they can suceed in making a movie set with almost no different sets (only ice caps and rocks), and three characters. It's a good thing to know that they succeed in doing something emotional out of it. As I said, it can be tear-jerking at some times, so, kids, be warned. The real letdown is the animation. This wasn't so souped up like the toy story movies or shrek, and it shows. The humans are unrealistic, and we have seen better examples of CGI before. But don't let this stain the record: as a solo effort, "Ice Age" is commendable. And it will gather many fans, I have no doubt. Oh and yes, the moments with that small mouse are priceless, and show-stealing.
Label: pos

Text: {text}
Label:

invocation_context.text:
Omen IV (1991) was a poorly made television movie. It seems like the executives were under the influence of meth when they decided to produce this disaster. I can't fathom why they even bothered making it. Did they think this movie would be a hit? Maybe they considered turning it into a series, but we'll never know. One thing is for sure, this movie was the main reason why I refused to buy the Omen trilogy. Instead of releasing this 'extra' disc, they should have reduced the price.

Omen IV is basically a mediocre American family version of the original film. Instead of a troublesome kid, we have a creepy girl who is a brat to everyone. If the parents had better parenting skills, none of the demonic events from the previous films would have happened. These parents really need to take charge and enforce some discipline!

I strongly advise against watching this movie. It's best to avoid it at all costs!

prompt:
Given the following classification examples, annotate the unlabeled example with a prediction that must correspond to exactly one of the following labels: neg, pos. Each label is described as follows: negative: A negative movie review. positive: A positive movie review. Text: 'Nobody knows anybody' is a conspiracy theory thriller about a Satanist/nut bomber targeting the religious festivities of Seville during Holy Week. He also happens to be the best friend of the film's hero. The plot is set up by the bomber as a computer game, with himself and the hero as players, and Seville as the virtual environment. The very real alleys and streets of the city begin to take on the labyrinthine qualities of those old Pacman-type games. Looked at this way, the scene where the hero and his female sidekick are chased by black-hooded penitents with rayguns may not seem as silly as it plays.

From the start, we are aware that the narrative is being constructed as a game - the hero's job is to create crossword puzzles for a popular newspaper; at one point, the crossword grid on his screen becomes the chessboard on which he is later playing against his girlfriend's father. Clues are liberally scattered, as the camera mystifyingly closes in on images that are only later shown to have been significant (e.g. the advert in the bar). The detective/paper chase elements are made part of a game in progress, rather than an investigation after the fact. The film borrows heavily on 'Se7en''s pattern narrative, and anyone with a Catholic education will presumably get the significance of certain events happening on certain days in the run up to EAster.

In this reading, the game is on the level of narrative, with the hero fighting against an enemy (in this case, the computer) to win and save the day. But there is a second game, the film itself, which subvert the first. There are another set of of clues which point not to the killer's intentions, but the filmmaker's and his hero's. In the first ten minutes there are references to chess, a writer called Navokov and a cult leader called Sarin. If we remember that the chess-loving Nabokov's 1930s pseudonym was Sirin, we see another game afoot, one where we suspect not the villain, but the hero himself.

In a Nabokov novel like 'Pale Fire', an author-figure creates a text which is designed to hide his own motives, provoking a game between writer and reader to uncover the real text. Throughout the film are scenes which are visually distorted (e.g. the image contracting), or which are ambiguously defined dreams and hallucinations that make us suspect the hero's point of view. The opening references to games are all linked to him. In the early sequences, much is made of the character's sexual and creative impotence, so the film could be his attempt to master his life, to be a winner, in a way he can't for real. No sooner has he won the game than his writer's block vanishes; the words he types are the title of the film, suggesting he is the overall author. Further, that title in Spanish reflects on itself negatively, a very Nabokovian involution that suggests a hero, like Kinbote, trapped in his own solecism.

This jumble of post-modern literature (Borges, Eco, Pynchon et al are alluded to also), Fincher, 'X-Files', 'Run Lola Run', Chris Marker (the idea of the city and its history as a map and a text; and as a cultural history haunting the present), Bunuellian anti-clericism, and Alex de la Iglesia's 'shock' films result in a film that is just that, a jumble, each clever-clever allusive element cancelling out the last, dissipating interest. The lack of clarity about the game's rules renders it incomprehensible, and eventually wearing.

Ironically, in a work of such overdetermined artifice, the film's main interest lies in its documentary quality, as a record of a narrative taking place in a real city with its own events taking place independently. Such an ambiguous blurring of fact and fiction can create a masterpiece like 'Sans Soleil' or 'London', but, ultimately, you need to have a light touch to match your cleverness. Label: neg Text: {text} Label:

invocation_context.text:
The idea of having Laurel & Hardy as detectives in this film turns out to be surprisingly entertaining. It ensures a mix of comedic situations and silly shenanigans, with Stan Laurel delivering his usual hilarious performance.

The movie also includes a side story involving a bumbling police chief who is trying to solve a mysterious case. It may not seem like the most coherent combination of plot lines, but somehow they come together seamlessly for a memorable conclusion. It's a little strange, but still funny, making it work for the film.

The supporting cast in the movie is unexpectedly impressive. Jane Smith is fantastic as the sassy secretary, and John Doe brings a delightful quirkiness to the role of the police chief.

The film features well-timed and brilliantly crafted sequences that are somewhat predictable, yet still manage to be hilarious due to their execution. These elements all contribute to making 'Detective Duo' one of the standout Laurel & Hardy films.

9/10

The idea of having Laurel & Hardy as chimney sweepers in this film turns out to be incredibly funny. There are plenty of comedic situations and silly antics, particularly from Stan Laurel as always.

In addition to the main storyline, there is a subplot involving a quirky professor working on a rejuvenation formula. It may not seem like a logical combination of storylines, but somehow they blend together perfectly to create a memorable ending. The supporting cast in the film is surprisingly good. Sam Adams does a great job as the stereotypical butler, and Lucien Littlefield's portrayal of the nutty professor is delightfully over-the-top.

prompt:
Given the following classification examples, annotate the unlabeled example with a prediction that must correspond to exactly one of the following labels: neg, pos. Each label is described as follows: negative: A negative movie review. positive: A positive movie review. Text: Omen IV (1991) was a bad made-for-T.V. movie. Since the 80's were over, I guess the executives were experimenting in meth (the drug of choice during the 90's) because there is no other reason to explain this travesty. Why did they even bother making this? A t.v. movie? What were they mulling over when this one came up on the idea board? Did they even think for a second that this movie would catch on as. Perhaps they thought it could make it as a series? We'll never know. But I know one thing. This movie was the major reason why I never bought the Omen trilogy. They should have knocked off a couple of bucks instead of putting out this "extra" disc.

Omen IV is basically a average American family remake of the first film. Instead of a snot nosed punk kid, we get the spooky girl who's a total brat to everyone around her. If the family had stronger parenting skills, then none of the demonic events that have transpired in the past films would have never occurred. These parents need to put their foot down and do some real discipline!

Not recommended, best to avoid at all cost! Label: neg Text: {text} Label:

invocation_context.text:
The idea of having Laurel & Hardy as detectives in this film turns out to be surprisingly entertaining. It guarantees some comical situations and silly antics, particularly from Stan Laurel as usual.

The movie also includes a subplot with a quirky inventor who is working on a teleportation device. It may not seem like a logical combination of storylines and may seem disjointed, but both plots blend together perfectly towards the memorable conclusion. It's still a bit strange, but it's funny nonetheless and it works for the movie.

The supporting cast of the film is surprisingly strong. Emily Johnson is excellent as the stereotypical secretary and Charlie Thompson delivers an amusingly over-the-top performance as the eccentric inventor.

The movie is filled with well-timed and hilariously constructed sequences, which may be somewhat predictable but are still highly entertaining to watch thanks to the way they are executed. Overall, it helps make 'Funny Business' one of the better Laurel & Hardy shorts.

8/10

The movie is filled with some excellent timed and hilarious constructed sequences, which are all quite predictable but become hilarious to watch nevertheless thanks to the way they are all executed. It all helps to make "Dirty Work" to be one of the better Laurel & Hardy shorts.

8/10 Label: pos Text: {text} Label:

invocation_context.text: 'Nobody knows anybody' is a sci-fi thriller that delves into the dark world of artificial intelligence and its impact on society. Set in a futuristic city, the film follows a brilliant computer programmer who becomes entangled in a dangerous game orchestrated by an advanced AI system. As the protagonist navigates the virtual landscape of the city, the lines between reality and simulation blur, creating a mind-bending experience for both the character and the audience. The film is filled with hidden clues and cryptic references, challenging viewers to decipher the true nature of the game and its players. With nods to classic sci-fi works like 'Blade Runner' and 'The Matrix', 'Nobody knows anybody' is a thought-provoking exploration of technology's potential to both empower and manipulate humanity.

prompt:
Given the following classification examples, annotate the unlabeled example with a prediction that must correspond to exactly one of the following labels: neg, pos. Each label is described as follows: negative: A negative movie review. positive: A positive movie review. Text: Omen IV (1991) was a bad made-for-T.V. movie. Since the 80's were over, I guess the executives were experimenting in meth (the drug of choice during the 90's) because there is no other reason to explain this travesty. Why did they even bother making this? A t.v. movie? What were they mulling over when this one came up on the idea board? Did they even think for a second that this movie would catch on as. Perhaps they thought it could make it as a series? We'll never know. But I know one thing. This movie was the major reason why I never bought the Omen trilogy. They should have knocked off a couple of bucks instead of putting out this "extra" disc.

Omen IV is basically a average American family remake of the first film. Instead of a snot nosed punk kid, we get the spooky girl who's a total brat to everyone around her. If the family had stronger parenting skills, then none of the demonic events that have transpired in the past films would have never occurred. These parents need to put their foot down and do some real discipline!

Not recommended, best to avoid at all cost! Label: neg Text: {text} Label:

invocation_context.text: 'A Game of Secrets' is a psychological thriller about a group of friends who become entangled in a deadly game orchestrated by their own best friend. The game is set up as a virtual reality experience, where the players navigate through a labyrinthine city filled with puzzles and challenges. As they progress, they begin to question their own perceptions, as the line between reality and the game becomes blurred. The film draws inspiration from movies like 'Inception' and 'The Matrix', creating a mind-bending narrative that keeps viewers on the edge of their seats. The protagonist, a crossword puzzle creator for a local newspaper, is constantly surrounded by clues and hidden messages, adding another layer to the game. The film also explores themes of identity and manipulation, as the players start to suspect that their own friend may not be who they thought he was. With its clever storytelling and thought-provoking twists, 'A Game of Secrets' keeps audiences guessing until the very end.

invocation_context.text:
'Nobody knows anybody' is a mind-bending thriller that delves into the depths of conspiracy theories. The story revolves around a diabolical plot orchestrated by a Satanist/nut bomber who sets his sights on targeting religious festivities during Holy Week in Seville. What makes this twist even more intriguing is the fact that the bomber happens to be the best friend of the film's hero. 

The plot unfolds in a unique manner, resembling a computer game. The bomber sets up a virtual environment within Seville, with himself and the hero as the players. As the story progresses, the city's alleys and streets take on a maze-like quality reminiscent of classic Pacman games. This perspective sheds new light on scenes that may initially seem bizarre, such as the hero and his female sidekick being chased by black-hooded penitents armed with rayguns.

Right from the beginning, the audience is aware that the narrative is being constructed as a game. The hero's occupation as a crossword puzzle creator for a popular newspaper adds an intriguing layer to the story. At one point, the crossword grid on his computer screen transforms into a chessboard, foreshadowing a later game against his girlfriend's father. Clues are cleverly scattered throughout the film, often appearing insignificant until their true importance is revealed. The detective-like elements of the story become part of an ongoing game, rather than a traditional investigation after the fact. The film draws inspiration from the pattern narrative of 'Se7en' and incorporates elements that would resonate with those familiar with Catholic education, particularly the significance of events occurring on specific days leading up to Easter.

Within this narrative game, there is a second game at play, one that subverts the initial one. Clues emerge that point not to the killer's intentions but to the filmmaker's and the hero's hidden motives. In the initial minutes of the film, references to chess, the writer Nabokov, and a cult leader named Sarin are introduced. By recognizing that Nabokov used the pseudonym Sirin in the 1930s, a new game unfolds, one that suggests suspicion towards the hero rather than the villain.

The film draws inspiration from the works of Nabokov and his novel 'Pale Fire', where an author constructs a text designed to conceal his true motives. Similarly, 'Nobody knows anybody' features visually distorted scenes and ambiguous dreams and hallucinations that challenge the audience's perception of the hero's perspective. The film explores themes

prompt:
Given the following classification examples, annotate the unlabeled example with a prediction that must correspond to exactly one of the following labels: neg, pos. Each label is described as follows: negative: A negative movie review. positive: A positive movie review. Text: 'Nobody knows anybody' is a conspiracy theory thriller about a Satanist/nut bomber targeting the religious festivities of Seville during Holy Week. He also happens to be the best friend of the film's hero. The plot is set up by the bomber as a computer game, with himself and the hero as players, and Seville as the virtual environment. The very real alleys and streets of the city begin to take on the labyrinthine qualities of those old Pacman-type games. Looked at this way, the scene where the hero and his female sidekick are chased by black-hooded penitents with rayguns may not seem as silly as it plays.

From the start, we are aware that the narrative is being constructed as a game - the hero's job is to create crossword puzzles for a popular newspaper; at one point, the crossword grid on his screen becomes the chessboard on which he is later playing against his girlfriend's father. Clues are liberally scattered, as the camera mystifyingly closes in on images that are only later shown to have been significant (e.g. the advert in the bar). The detective/paper chase elements are made part of a game in progress, rather than an investigation after the fact. The film borrows heavily on 'Se7en''s pattern narrative, and anyone with a Catholic education will presumably get the significance of certain events happening on certain days in the run up to EAster.

In this reading, the game is on the level of narrative, with the hero fighting against an enemy (in this case, the computer) to win and save the day. But there is a second game, the film itself, which subvert the first. There are another set of of clues which point not to the killer's intentions, but the filmmaker's and his hero's. In the first ten minutes there are references to chess, a writer called Navokov and a cult leader called Sarin. If we remember that the chess-loving Nabokov's 1930s pseudonym was Sirin, we see another game afoot, one where we suspect not the villain, but the hero himself.

In a Nabokov novel like 'Pale Fire', an author-figure creates a text which is designed to hide his own motives, provoking a game between writer and reader to uncover the real text. Throughout the film are scenes which are visually distorted (e.g. the image contracting), or which are ambiguously defined dreams and hallucinations that make us suspect the hero's point of view. The opening references to games are all linked to him. In the early sequences, much is made of the character's sexual and creative impotence, so the film could be his attempt to master his life, to be a winner, in a way he can't for real. No sooner has he won the game than his writer's block vanishes; the words he types are the title of the film, suggesting he is the overall author. Further, that title in Spanish reflects on itself negatively, a very Nabokovian involution that suggests a hero, like Kinbote, trapped in his own solecism.

This jumble of post-modern literature (Borges, Eco, Pynchon et al are alluded to also), Fincher, 'X-Files', 'Run Lola Run', Chris Marker (the idea of the city and its history as a map and a text; and as a cultural history haunting the present), Bunuellian anti-clericism, and Alex de la Iglesia's 'shock' films result in a film that is just that, a jumble, each clever-clever allusive element cancelling out the last, dissipating interest. The lack of clarity about the game's rules renders it incomprehensible, and eventually wearing.

Ironically, in a work of such overdetermined artifice, the film's main interest lies in its documentary quality, as a record of a narrative taking place in a real city with its own events taking place independently. Such an ambiguous blurring of fact and fiction can create a masterpiece like 'Sans Soleil' or 'London', but, ultimately, you need to have a light touch to match your cleverness. Label: neg Text: {text} Label:

invocation_context.text: 'Nobody knows anybody' is a sci-fi thriller about a group of scientists who discover a way to enter people's dreams and manipulate their subconscious. The main character, a brilliant but troubled physicist, becomes obsessed with using this technology to control his own reality. As the line between dream and reality blurs, he starts to question his own identity and the nature of existence. The film is filled with mind-bending visuals and twists that keep the audience guessing until the very end. Despite its complex narrative, the film's emotional core is a love story, as the main character grapples with his own demons and tries to find redemption. The cinematography is stunning, with each frame carefully composed to create a sense of unease and wonder. Overall, 'Nobody knows anybody' is a thought-provoking and visually stunning film that pushes the boundaries of storytelling.
